yeah i'm not sure anyone would consider an MLM an authoritative source on anything other than how to get rich from gullible people

not a synonym. description of zest not necessary in lead of this article so just removed.

/* Culinary uses */ This should have been up there. Something glitched.
/* Peel */ Minor Edit to put leaves in their proper sub-category.
/* Culinary uses */ Inaccuracy.  "Zest" is a form of grating the peel, but only one of many uses of the peel. Sub-section the category for easier finds.
/* Culinary uses */ Missing are preserved lemons, a technique common to Moroccan cooking but finding its way into Italian, Greek, and French cuisines as well.
Replacing arbitrary hatnote with standard distinction.

clean up formatting; references kept consistent date formatting

Citric acid is included in the "carbohydrates" (even though it is not a carbohydrate), but it has a lower contribution to the food energy than true carbohydrates such as sugars.
/* History */ cited source says second century
/* Nutritional value and phytochemicals */Journal cites: fix volume param,  using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (12142)
move images to gallery, prod table & nutrition table for content alignment
/* Production */ table edit for last available data, 2013; reduce no.of countries, present only 2013 results

Remove information uncited for more than, and I'm not kidding here, four years

Added effect of lemons on DNA repair.
Fixed spelling of cross reference so it works.
/* Nutritional value and phytochemicals */ rv unnecessary comment about citric acid

In the Nutritional value template, we have to say "carbs", not "carbohydrates". This includes a lot of citric acid, which is not exactly a carbohydrate. The energy figure does not include energy from citric acid.

removed reiteration of statement made in the previous sentence
Mayer did not "discover" the variety. The Chinese had done that centuries earlier.
hybrid name is not an appropriate link for a multiplication sign
/* Culinary uses */ lemon curd very popular in UK (very little lemon marmalade)

Lemon (1. name of the tree and 2. name of the fruit)

removed original research claiming that there is only a single lemon. The sources show that there are in fact more than one lemon so A lemon makes more sense and better serves the reader. See [[Lime]] for an example of using A not the.
Nah, "the" is used throughout ("The 'Bonnie Brae' is oblong", "The 'Eureka' ... is the common supermarket lemon", "The 'Ponderosa' is" etc.)
changed the lemon to a lemon.

Reference tidy. Names of newspapers go in italics, so in "cite news", the source is "newspaper" or "work", rather than "publisher". Doing this automatically puts it into italics.
/* Varieties */  Unsourced for over a year since April 2013.
using a higher resolution and better license pic for infobox
